DOC.HEAD: Soviet Students To Tour SAC Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: Eight Soviet students will tour the underground Strategic Air Command headquarters Friday in what may be the first such tour of the nuclear weapons command center, officials said Monday. Col. Larry Greer, a SAC spokesman, said it was coincidental that the tour comes amid changes in Eastern Europe and improved Soviet-American relations. But school officials might have never considered asking SAC for the tour if it weren't for the apparently improving relations, said Di Saggau, a spokeswoman for the Westside Community Schools. The tour of SAC underground is apparently the first by a Soviet group, and it will be a little different from other tours, Greer said. ``We're not going to bear down on nuclear deterence,'' although that is part of SAC's mission, Greer said. ``It's a fact. It's well known. If they can read, they know it.'' SAC is the Air Force's long-range strike force of manned bombers and intercontinental ballistic missiles. Since 1961, it has flown round-the-clock flights in project Looking Glass, which would take charge of nuclear forces if the president and other leaders were killed. Five Soviet girls and three boys, ages 15-17, have been in the United States since Nov. 27 in an exchange program with Westside High School. They are to leave Dec. 27, and a group of Westside students is to visit the Soviet Union in March. The Soviet students' teacher-interpreter and eight American students will accompany them on the SAC tour, Saggau and Greer said. SAC, at Offutt Air Force Base near Omaha, will follow its normal security precautions for civilians, including keeping the group together on the tour, Greer said. SAC officials will modify the Soviet briefing because of language concerns and because they think teen-agers are more interested in the technological gadgets and wizardry than in broad policy, he said. The students also will make radio contact with a base in Alaska. ``I want to remind the Soviet kids that we're just a few miles west of them,'' Greer said.
